ma6:1.2: One time, the Buddha traveled to the country of Śrāvastī and stayed at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove.
ma6:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
ma6:2.2: “I will explain for you the seven places to which a good person goes and nirvāṇa without remainder.
ma6:3.1: The monks then accepted the teaching and listened.
ma6:4.0: 1. Like Chaff that Burns and Goes Out
ma6:4.3: A monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:4.4: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:4.5: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:4.6: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:4.7: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:4.8: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:5.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:5.2: It’s like setting fire to wheat chaff, which burns a little and then goes out.
ma6:5.3: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:5.4: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa in the interim.
ma6:5.5: This is called the first place to which a good person goes.
ma6:5.6: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:6.0: 2. Like a Spark that Flies Up and Goes Out
ma6:6.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:6.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:6.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:6.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:6.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:6.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:7.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:7.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s glowing and flaming hot with a hammer, and a spark flies off and goes out after rising.
ma6:7.3: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:7.4: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa in the interim.
ma6:7.5: This is called the second place to which a good person goes.
ma6:7.6: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:8.0: 3. Like a Spark that Goes Out as It Fall Back Down
ma6:8.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:8.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:8.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:8.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:8.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:8.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:9.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:9.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s glowing and flaming hot with a hammer, and a spark flies off it.
ma6:9.3: After rising, it comes back down but goes out before reaching the ground.
ma6:9.4: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:9.5: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa in the interim.
ma6:9.6: This is called the third place to which a good person goes.
ma6:9.7: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:10.0: 4. Like a Spark that Goes Out after Falling to the Ground
ma6:10.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:10.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:10.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:10.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:10.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:10.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:11.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:11.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s blazing and flaming hot with a hammer, and a spark flies off, falls to the ground, and goes out.
ma6:11.3: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:11.4: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa at birth.
ma6:11.5: This is called the fourth place to which a good person goes.
ma6:11.6: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:12.0: 5. Like a Spark that Sets Fire to Some Grass and Goes Out
ma6:12.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:12.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:12.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:12.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:12.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:12.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:13.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:13.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s glowing and flaming hot with a hammer, and a spark flies off it.
ma6:13.3: It falls onto a little wood or grass that smokes or burns, and then it goes out after burning.
ma6:13.4: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:13.5: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa with practice.
ma6:13.6: This is called the fifth place to which a good person goes.
ma6:13.7: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:14.0: 6. Like a Spark that Completely Burns Up Some Grass
ma6:14.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:14.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:14.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:14.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:14.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:14.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:15.1: “Where will a monk go who practices in this way?
ma6:15.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s glowing and flaming hot with a hammer, and a spark flies off it.
ma6:15.3: It falls onto much wood or grass that smokes or burns, and then goes out after burning it up completely.
ma6:15.4: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:15.5: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa without practice.
ma6:15.6: This is called the sixth place to which a good person goes.
ma6:15.7: The world in truth does have such people.
ma6:16.0: 7. Like a Spark that Burns Up a Large Area
ma6:16.1: “Furthermore, a monk’s practice ought to be thus:
ma6:16.2: ‘I have no self, and nothing is mine.
ma6:16.3: In the future, there’ll be no self, and nothing will be mine.’
ma6:16.4: He then ends what has been, and he attains equanimity after ending it.
ma6:16.5: The pleasures he has don’t stain him, and he doesn’t cling to what has come together.
ma6:16.6: Such a practitioner sees by the wisdom of unsurpassed stillness, but he has yet to attain its realization.
ma6:17.1: “Where will a monk who practices thus go?
ma6:17.2: It’s like striking an iron that’s both glowing and flaming with a hammer, and a spark flies off it.
ma6:17.3: It falls onto much wood or grass that smokes or burns.
ma6:17.4: Once it’s burning, it then sets fire to a town, a city, a forested mountain, or a wilderness.
ma6:17.5: After it burns that town, city, forested mountain, or wilderness, it might reach a road, water line, or a plain and go out.
ma6:17.6: You should know that monk to be likewise.
ma6:17.7: With a little conceit that’s yet to end, he has cut the five lower bonds and will attain parinirvāṇa upstream in Akaniṣṭha.
ma6:17.8: This is called the seventh place to which a good person goes.
ma6:17.9: The world in truth does have such people.

ma6:19.1: “I say that monk doesn’t go east, and he doesn’t go west, south, north, the four counterpoints, up, or down.
ma6:19.2: In the present life, he’s been stilled and completely liberated.
ma6:20.1: “I had said, ‘I will explain the seven places to which a good person goes and nirvāṇa without remainder,’ and so I have explained it.”
ma6:21.2: Those monks who heard what the Buddha taught rejoiced and approved.
